Some of my tests methods contain logic like this:

         XMLReader crimson;
         try {
             crimson = XMLReaderFactory.createXMLReader(
               "org.apache.crimson.parser.XMLReaderImpl");
         }
         catch (SAXException ex) {
             // can't test Crimson if you can't load it
             return;
         }
        // OK. We found Crimson. Now let's run the test

In other words, I'm testing a workaround for a bug in a particular class 
that may or may not be present. Such tests might also depend on 
platform, java version, or other environmental conditions. In JUnit 3 if 
I can't really make the test due to environmental problems I only have 
two options: pass or fail. Neither is really satisfactory or properly 
explains what;s happening.

In JUnit 4 we can annotate a test as @Ignore. However that's only good 
at compile time. What I want is an ignore() or skip() method similar to 
the fail() method. However this method signals that a test was skipped 
instead of failed. Is there such a method already? If not, could we have 
one please? I looked but I couldn't find one in the current code base, 
but then I just wasn't looking in the right place.
